description: Philadelphia has hired a service to clean up after violent shootings outdoors. The idea is to minimize community trauma when neighbors do the cleaning themselves or firefighters hose away the blood.
title: A clean up service will deal with shooting aftermath to minimize community trauma

description: The National Weather Service had issued heat advisories for parts of at least 15 states, including in several major cities such as Philadelphia, Columbus and Boston.
title: Millions of Americans are under heat advisories as high temperatures roast the U.S.

description:
This year's college application process was supposed to get easier.

That's because last year, the U.S. Department of Education announced changes to the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or FAFSA.

The problems with the FAFSA form began last fall.

And with August and September around the corner, some applicants continue to experience technical issues.

Before this year, students would already know how much aid they're getting. But in 2024, not knowing, which is the case for many, could mean they can't go to college.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
title: Federal student aid still up in the air for many

description: The first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season has arrived. Tropical Storm Alberto is heading west towards Mexico, bringing heavy rains, coastal flooding and possible hurricanes to Texas.
title: Tropical Storm Alberto, the first of the season, drenches Texas en route to Mexico

description: President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signed the comprehensive strategic partnership treaty after their summit in Pyongyang on Wednesday.
title: Russia and North Korea vow stronger partnership against the West with new treaty

description: The Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, D.C., is emerging from a four-year metamorphosis. Eighty-two copies of Shakespeare’s “First Folio” will be together on public display for the first time.
title: Much Ado About First Folios — the world's largest Shakespeare collection reopens

description: With electronic shelf labels, prices can change up to six times a minute. Grocers including Walmart, Whole Foods and Schnucks are adopting them.
title: A supermarket trip may soon look different, thanks to electronic shelf labels

description: Managers are still troubleshooting a number of thruster issues and helium leaks on the capsule's first crewed flight test.
title: NASA has delayed the undocking of Boeing's Starliner capsule until next week

description: The fires are threatening the village of Ruidoso. Tribal, state and federal officials are scrambling to save homes and lives.
title: 2 fast-growing wildfires have upended the lives of thousands of people near Ruidoso, N.M.

description: NPR's Leila Fadel talks with Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas about the Biden administration's immigration orders.
title: Does Biden's plan to protect millions from deportation square with border tightening?

description: Opal Lee, the activist known as the grandmother of Juneteenth, worked hard to see it become a federal holiday. NPR's Michel Martin reflects on why it's a holiday for all Americans.
title: Juneteenth isn’t just a Black holiday. It’s for all Americans

description: A politically connected Missouri couple allegedly poisoned their neighbor's trees to secure their million-dollar view of Camden Harbor in Maine. The incident was unearthed by the victim herself.
title: Poisoned trees gave a wealthy couple a killer view -- and united residents in outrage

description: Mays' Hall-of-Fame career spanned more than two decades, from the 1950s to 1970s. He spent nearly all of those years with the Giants – first in New York and then in San Francisco.
title: Willie Mays, widely considered baseball's best all-around player, dies at 93

description: The mom whose remains were discovered in 1983 in what's now Lake Forest, Calif., was positively identified Friday by authorities as Maritza Glean Grimmett, says the Orange County Sheriff’s Department.
title: After 41 years, a missing woman has been identified. Police want to know how she died

description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Miami Chief Heat Officer Jane Gilbert about the measures she is taking to help residents during this week's heat wave.
title: Heat wave safety tips from the world's first chief heat officer

description: As Russia's leader visits North Korea, Johns Hopkins professor Sergey Radchenko offers insights into the fascinating history of twists and turns in relations between Moscow and Pyongyang.
title: Opinion: Putin and Kim forge closer ties, resuscitating a defunct Stalinist alliance

description: In 1996, Lorrie Paul was in the hospital, visiting her ailing father. As she sobbed in the hallway, a kind stranger walked by and offered comfort.
title: She was sobbing in the hospital hallway — then felt a comforting hand on her shoulder

description: This week Maryland Gov. Wes Moore pardoned 175,000 people with marijuana convictions. But some advocates say pardons might not be enough to remove the barriers faced by people with a criminal record.
title: Some say Maryland’s mass marijuana pardons don’t go far enough

description: This summer bike riders from two Cherokee tribes are retracing the Trail of Tears. Along the way they'll learn about the forced removal of their ancestors.
title: Cyclists from 2 Cherokee tribes are retracing the Trail of Tears

description: NPR's Michel Martin talks to Jake Dunagan from the Institute for the Future, on the future of marriage in America.
title: The 'Morning Edition' series 'The Sumer of Love' begins with a look at marriage

description: NPR's Michel Martin talks to Jake Dunagan from the Institute for the Future, on the future of marriage in America.
title: The 'Morning Edition' series 'The Summer of Love' begins with a look at marriage

description: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun testifies on Capitol Hill. Two growing wildfires upend life in New Mexico. Ascension, one of the nation's largest health systems, deals with the effects of a ransomware attack.
title: Morning news brief

description: For Juneteenth on Morning Edition, professor Nathan Connolly reflects on the promise of the Emancipation Proclamation, and NPR staff voice the document in its entirety.
title: Observing Juneteenth with the reading of the Emancipation Proclamation

description: As climate change increases the intensity of wildfires, experts are struggling to prepare vulnerable communities for potential catastrophes. One new approach is a community-wide board game that tests resilience.
title: How a board game can help vulnerable communities prepare for catastrophic wildfires

description: A Palestinian American doctor says it's now much harder to enter Gaza with medical supplies. He places blame on Israel, Egypt and the U.S. for failing to improve the humanitarian situation .
title: Doctor urges U.S. to use its influence with Israel and Egypt to reopen Rafah crossing

description:
Today we bring you an episode from NPR's science podcast Short Wave about how Israel is using facial recognition software to track Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank. And what the proliferation of this technology means for privacy around the world.

You can find more Short Wave episodes here.
title: How is Israel Using Facial Recognition in Gaza?

description: The sentencing of Staff Sgt. Gordon Black on charges of stealing and threats of murder further complicates U.S. relations with Russia, which have grown increasingly tense over the fighting in Ukraine.
title: Russian court sentences U.S. soldier to nearly 4 years, state media reports
